headline: JWST phase-curve data hint TRAPPIST-1 b may have an atmosphere
plain_language_summary: TRAPPIST-1 b is an Earth-sized rocky planet that likely keeps the same face toward its star, so one side is in constant day and the other in constant night. The study analyzed JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy taken across an orbital phase curve to see how the planet’s thermal emission changes with phase and whether the spectrum shows atmospheric absorption. The authors report a dayside brightness temperature of 342 +/- 22 K and retrieve a non-zero heat transport efficiency (epsilon) of 0.19 (+0.23 / -0.14), which favors some redistribution of heat from day to night compared with the perfect no-atmosphere limit. They also report spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band (a band depth estimate of 96 ppm) that is consistent with atmospheric absorption. In the joint fit, atmosphere-bearing models are preferred over a no-atmosphere model (likelihood ratio 7.4 versus a 1.0 baseline). At the same time, the authors stress that atmospheric composition and pressure are still uncertain, that O2-rich cases are not fully ruled out, and that degeneracies and possible systematics mean follow-up spectroscopy is needed.
what_is_new: JWST MIRI collected low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve, enabling phase-resolved thermal spectra of TRAPPIST-1 b.
The retrieval favors non-zero heat redistribution (epsilon 0.19 (+0.23 / -0.14)) and reports structure near the 15 um CO2 band (96 ppm).
A joint fit prefers atmosphere-bearing models over a no-atmosphere model (likelihood ratio 7.4 compared to a 1.0 baseline).
why_caution_is_needed: This is a single-planet study and does not establish how common atmospheres are on similar rocky planets.
Model retrieval choices (circulation, opacity priors, and cloud treatment) can shift the inferred parameters.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics may bias weak spectral features such as subtle band structure.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset, limiting conclusions about global conditions.

glossary.definition: Measurements of a planet’s brightness as it moves through its orbit, which reveals how thermal emission changes from day side to night side.
A temperature that represents how bright an object appears in thermal radiation, used as a convenient way to summarize infrared emission.
The fraction of total incoming starlight reflected by a planet; a low Bond albedo means the planet absorbs most incident energy.
A parameter describing how effectively energy is redistributed from the day side to the night side; epsilon = 0 corresponds to no redistribution.
A statistical inference approach that compares forward models to observations to estimate atmospheric and thermal parameters from data.
An infrared wavelength region near 15 microns where carbon dioxide strongly absorbs, potentially imprinting a spectral feature if CO2 is present.

open_questions: Is any atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b CO2-rich, O2-rich, or something else, given that O2-rich cases are not fully ruled out?
What is the true surface pressure and how tightly can it be constrained beyond the plausible 0.3–1.0 bar family in CO2-rich retrievals?
How much do clouds/hazes and circulation assumptions contribute to the remaining degeneracies in the phase-curve and spectral interpretation?
Will additional JWST observations confirm the reported 15 um structure and reduce the impact of stellar variability and instrument systematics?
